title: 010 Android OrmLite over SQLite example
ORMLite
b

is an Object Relational Mapping package that provides simple and lightweight functionality for persisting Java objects to SQL databases while avoiding the complexity and overhead of more standard ORM packages.

inline_content.Text: ORMLite

is an Object Relational Mapping package that provides simple and lightweight functionality for persisting Java objects to SQL databases while avoiding the complexity and overhead of more standard ORM packages.

title: Speaking for Android, OrmLite is implemented over the out-of-the-box supported database, SQLite. It makes direct calls to the API to access SQLite.

inline_content.Text: Speaking for Android, OrmLite is implemented over the out-of-the-box supported database, SQLite. It makes direct calls to the API to access SQLite.

title: Gradle setup

inline_content.Text: Gradle setup

title: To get started you should include the package to the build gradle.

inline_content.Text: To get started you should include the package to the build gradle.

title: Then you should configure a POJO to be persisted to the database. Here care must be taken to the annotations:

inline_content.Text: Then you should configure a POJO to be persisted to the database. Here care must be taken to the annotations:

title: Add the @DatabaseTable annotation to the top of each class. You can also use @Entity.

inline_content.Text: Add the @DatabaseTable annotation to the top of each class. You can also use @Entity.

title: Add the @DatabaseField annotation right before each field to be persisted. You can also use @Column and others.

inline_content.Text: Add the @DatabaseField annotation right before each field to be persisted. You can also use @Column and others.

title: Add a no-argument constructor to each class with at least package visibility.

inline_content.Text: Add a no-argument constructor to each class with at least package visibility.

title: At the example above there is one table (form_model) with 4 fields.

inline_content.Text: At the example above there is one table (form_model) with 4 fields.

title: id field is auto generated index.

inline_content.Text: id field is auto generated index.

title: username is an index to the database.

inline_content.Text: username is an index to the database.

title: More information about the annotation can be found at the
official documentation
a
http://ormlite.com/javadoc/ormlite-core/doc-files/ormlite_2.html#Local-Annotations

inline_content.Text: More information about the annotation can be found at the
official documentation

title: Database Helper

inline_content.Text: Database Helper

title: To continue with, you will need to create a database helper class which should extend the OrmLiteSqliteOpenHelper class.

inline_content.Text: To continue with, you will need to create a database helper class which should extend the OrmLiteSqliteOpenHelper class.

title: This class creates and upgrades the database when your application is installed and can also provide the DAO classes used by your other classes.

inline_content.Text: This class creates and upgrades the database when your application is installed and can also provide the DAO classes used by your other classes.

title: DAO stands for Data Access Object and it provides all the scrum functionality and specializes in the handling a single persisted class.

inline_content.Text: DAO stands for Data Access Object and it provides all the scrum functionality and specializes in the handling a single persisted class.

title: The helper class must implement the following two methods:

inline_content.Text: The helper class must implement the following two methods:

title: onCreate(SQLiteDatabase sqliteDatabase, ConnectionSource connectionSource);

inline_content.Text: onCreate(SQLiteDatabase sqliteDatabase, ConnectionSource connectionSource);

title: onCreate creates the database when your app is first installed

inline_content.Text: onCreate creates the database when your app is first installed

title: onUpgrade(SQLiteDatabase database, ConnectionSource connectionSource, int oldVersion, int newVersion);

inline_content.Text: onUpgrade(SQLiteDatabase database, ConnectionSource connectionSource, int oldVersion, int newVersion);

title: onUpgrade handles the upgrading of the database tables when you upgrade your app to a new version

inline_content.Text: onUpgrade handles the upgrading of the database tables when you upgrade your app to a new version
